thread.title: Anti-tax group on Trump's Iowa slump: 'We told you so'
thread.title_full: Anti-tax group on Trump's Iowa slump: 'We told you so' | Washington Examiner

author: Gabby Morrongiello
title: Anti-tax group on Trump's Iowa slump: 'We told you so'
text:
As Donald Trump falls to second place in Iowa behind retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, one conservative group is telling voters: "We told you so."
Roughly two weeks ahead of the latest Quinnipiac University and Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics polls showing Carson edging Trump in the earliest voting state, a super PAC affiliated with the fiscally conservative Club for Growth released its own poll indicating Trump was headed for trouble.
"Two days, and two more polls with the same message that Club for Growth Action reported on October 6: Donald Trump lost his lead in Iowa," the group's president, David McIntosh, said in a statement Friday.
"CFG Action ran $1 million of television ads in Iowa exposing Donald Trump's extremely positions on taxes, healthcare, bailouts, and property rights, and the polls have made it clear: Trump loses when voters know the truth about him," McIntosh added.
  Clinton wins endorsement from major public-sector union AFSCME A union for state and local government workers says she has the best chance among labor-friendly candidates.
By Sean Higgins • 10/23/15 1:41 PM Related Story: http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2574118/ While the original CFG Action poll found Trump trailing Carson by 5 percentage points (16-21 percent) among likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa, new polls illustrate a larger gap between the two outsider candidates.
The DMR/Bloomberg Politics poll released Friday shows Carson leading Trump by nearly 10 points with 28 percent support. Meanwhile, the billionaire stands at 19 percent support among Iowa Republicans.
In late September, Trump's campaign sent a "cease and desist" letter to McIntosh that threatened to sue his organization for their attack ads against Trump in the Hawkeye State.
"We will not sit idly by and allow special interest groups and political action committees like yours to defame Mr. Trump and cause damage to his reputation and business interests," the letter reportedly said.
